text: The CCPP-ARM Parameterization Testbed (CAPT): A Strategic Plan
label: HH2

text: (Last update 28 April 2003)
label: HH3

text: 1. Introduction
label: HH2

text: Climate simulations performed with general circulation models (GCMs) are widely viewed
label: BODY

text: as the principal scientific basis for developing policies to address potential future global change
label: BODY

text: scenarios (e.g. global warming, ozone depletion, changes in land use, etc.). Hence, there is a
label: BODY

text: compelling need to systematically improve the performance of GCMs in simulating the present
label: BODY

text: climate, and thereby to reduce their uncertainties in predicting climate change (e.g. Goody et al.
label: BODY

text: 2002).  This endeavor requires a two-pronged strategy that entails
label: BODY

text: • comparison of GCM simulations with observations over a broad range of time scales in
label: BODY

text: order to diagnose the details of the associated simulation errors, and
label: BODY

text: • reduction of these errors by improving representations of key physical processes and
label: BODY

text: feedback mechanisms, thereby enhancing the physical realism of GCM climate
label: BODY

text: simulations.
label: BODY

text: Much of our collective understanding of current strengths and weaknesses of GCM climate
label: BODY

text: simulations comes from periodic assessments of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
label: BODY

text: (IPCC 2001).  These, in turn, are largely based on the findings of model intercomparison projects
label: BODY

text: organized chiefly by the World Climate Research Programme (e.g. WCRP 2001).
label: BODY

text: In particular, a wealth of model-performance information is provided by the Atmospheric
label: BODY

text: Model Intercomparison Project (AMIP) in which some 30 GCMs, with common forcing by
label: BODY

text: observed ocean boundary conditions, are simulating the present climate (Gates 1992).  On
label: BODY

text: distilling the many technical details of the first AMIP experiment (e.g. Gates et al. 1999), an
label: BODY

text: intriguing result emerges:  the climate simulations of GCMs designed mainly for numerical
label: BODY

text: weather prediction (NWP) are surprisingly "competitive" with those of GCMs designed
label: BODY

text: expressly for climate studies.  This outcome arguably stems from NWP modelers' adoption of a
label: BODY

text: standard diagnostic protocol, which is summarized as follows.
label: BODY

text: GCMs designed for numerical weather prediction (hereafter, "NWP GCMs") are developed
label: BODY

text: so as to optimize their short-range (~ 0-72 hour) forecast performance, as evaluated against either
label: BODY

text: observations or NWP analyses that are synthesize observations and model-derived quantities.
label: BODY

text: However, even though an NWP GCM usually is run at comparatively high resolution (~ 0.5x0.5-
label: BODY

text: degree grid and ~ 30+ vertical layers), it cannot explicitly resolve many phenomena (e.g.
label: BODY

text: individual clouds and associated radiation, precipitation and related microphysics, turbulent
label: BODY

text: boundary layer processes, etc.).   These effects must be parameterized in terms of the model's
label: BODY

text: resolved variables, and deficiencies in these parameterizations are identified by diagnosing
label: BODY

text: discrepancies between
label: BODY

text: 1) model forecasts and NWP analyses,
label: BODY

text: 2) model forecasts and observations that are not assimilated in the NWP analyses (e.g.
label: BODY

text: clouds, precipitation, etc.), and
label: BODY

text: 3) NWP analyses and observations.
label: BODY

text: The efficacy of modifying selected parameterizations is assessed according to whether such
label: BODY

text: changes increase the skill of the GCM's short-range forecasts and/or improve the NWP analyses.
label: BODY

text: If these parameterization changes also improve model performance at time scales longer than the
label: BODY

text: deterministic forecast range of ~15 days (owing to reductions in systematic model biases), the
label: BODY

text: new schemes are included in the next-generation NWP GCM.  When this diagnostic protocol is
label: BODY

text: followed rigorously, the new GCM also has a higher probability of performing well in simulating
label: BODY

text: climate (seasonal, inter-annual, and multi-annual) time scales, provided that the new
label: BODY

text: parameterizations function satisfactorily at the coarser resolutions (~3x3-degrees and ~15
label: BODY

text: vertical layers) typical of GCMs designed for climate simulation (hereafter, "climate GCMs").
label: BODY

text: Owing to the demonstrated improvements in model performance resulting from applying
label: BODY

text: such a diagnostic protocol to NWP GCMs, the WCRP's Working Group on Numerical
label: BODY

text: Experimentation has advocated a ‘Transpose AMIP’ project (WGNE 1999) to encourage
label: BODY

text: adoption of similar methods for coarse-resolution climate GCMs. Practical impetus for this effort
label: BODY

text: now is being provided by a new U.S. Department of Energy (USDOE) initiative: the CCPP-
label: BODY

text: ARM Parameterization Testbed (CAPT).
label: BODY

text: CAPT will apply the first component of the NWP diagnostic protocol (comparison of model
label: BODY

text: forecasts with analyses) to climate GCMs that are supported by the USDOE Climate Change
label: BODY

text: Prediction Program (CCPP).  In addition, CAPT will implement the second component of this
label: BODY

text: diagnostic protocol (comparison of GCM forecasts with observations not assimilated in the
label: BODY

text: analyses) by employing USDOE Atmospheric Radiation Measurement (ARM) observations and
label: BODY

text: similar field data for model evaluation. Moreover, CAPT will foster closer collaborations
label: BODY

text: between GCM developers and parameterization specialists, especially those funded under the
label: BODY

text: CCPP and ARM Programs.  Finally, CAPT will supply evaluation data and diagnostic software
label: BODY

text: in a form that can be conveniently applied to climate GCMs.
label: BODY

text: The remainder of this paper discusses the CAPT strategy, first by explaining its scientific
label: BODY

text: rationale in Section 2, then by outlining the proposed diagnostic protocol in Section 3, and
label: BODY

text: finally by elaborating relevant technical details in Section 4.  A brief summary is given in
label: BODY

text: Section 5.
label: BODY

text: CAPT: Scientific Basis
label: HH3

text: 2.1 Perspective
label: HH2

text: The standard approach in developing a climate GCM is to focus on whether a given
label: BODY

text: parameterization favorably impacts the model’s climate statistics and/or their perceived
label: BODY

text: departures from the observed climate, such as can be estimated from relatively sparse spatio-
label: BODY

text: temporal sampling. However, such an approach limits accurate identification of specific
label: BODY

text: parameterization deficiencies, since the GCM’s climate statistics reflect compensating errors in
label: BODY

text: the simulation of atmospheric dynamics as well as many different physical processes.
label: BODY

text: Instead, CAPT is advocating a different approach for parameterization testing: the use of
label: BODY

text: high-frequency (~6 hourly) NWP analyses both to realistically initialize a coarse-resolution
label: BODY

text: climate GCM and to evaluate the accuracy of its subsequent short-range weather forecasts. The
label: BODY

text: rationale is that most of the GCM's forecast error can be attributed to parameterization
label: BODY

text: deficiencies, once the model's dynamical state is initialized realistically.  This is especially true
label: BODY

text: when comparing analysis-initialized GCM forecasts with observations that are not assimilated in
label: BODY

text: the NWP analysis (e.g. radiative and turbulent fluxes, clouds, precipitation). Such unassimilated
label: BODY

text: observations can be obtained, for example, from ARM field data or satellite measurements.
label: BODY

text: There are other reasons as well to adopt this more physically based diagnostic protocol.
label: BODY

text: Because forecast skill can be readily quantified using standard NWP metrics, the effects of
label: BODY

text: modifying a parameterization can be objectively determined.  In addition, the rich variety of
label: BODY

text: weather phenomena allows GCM parameterizations to be comprehensively tested.  Moreover,
label: BODY

text: the short-range behavior of the GCM is relevant for climate simulation, since systematic model
label: BODY

text: errors often arise within the first few days of a simulation, and then just grow larger with time.
label: BODY

text: In principle, a climate GCM that demonstrates generally enhanced short-range forecast skill
label: BODY

text: also should show improved simulation of climate statistics, since these are aggregates of the
label: BODY

text: detailed evolution of the model, rather than stochastically predicted quantities.  Such
label: BODY

text: improvements must be demonstrated in practice, though, by first testing the parameterization in
label: BODY

text: GCM predictions beyond the deterministic range of  ~15 days, and then in long climate
label: BODY

text: simulations.  To the degree that connections exist between forecasting errors and climate errors,
label: BODY

text: the testing of GCM parameterizations also will proceed more efficiently by focusing attention
label: BODY

text: first on many short forecasts rather than a few long climate simulations.
label: BODY

text: Hence, CAPT's premise is that application of high-frequency NWP analyses to evaluate the
label: BODY

text: weather forecasts of climate GCMs is an effective technique for
label: BODY

text: identifying deficiencies in model parameterizations,
label: BODY

text: providing insights into the causes of these shortcomings, and
label: BODY

text: quantifying the impact of changes made to the models.
label: BODY

text: In applying this diagnostic protocol, CAPT's overriding goal is to improve GCM
label: BODY

text: performance--as manifested initially in short-range forecasts, but ultimately in climate
label: BODY

text: simulations.
label: BODY

text: 2.2 NWP analyses
label: HH2

text: It is evident that NWP analyses (remapped to the coarser resolution of a climate GCM) will
label: BODY

text: play a central role in the CAPT diagnostic protocol. The typical analysis is generated by a four-
label: BODY

text: dimensional data assimilation (FDDA) system that applies variational mathematics to optimally
label: BODY

text: estimate global weather from ingested surface, radiosonde, and satellite observations (Haltiner
label: BODY

text: and Williams 1980, Daley 1991).  This data assimilation also entails the application of an NWP
label: BODY

text: GCM--often the same model as that used for weather forecasting.
label: BODY

text: The success of the CAPT strategy hinges on the accuracy of the NWP analyses to be used
label: BODY

text: for evaluating the weather forecasts of the climate GCM.  Hollingsworth et al. (2002), for
label: BODY

text: example, have shown that the short-range forecasts of a representative NWP GCM track
label: BODY

text: observations of atmospheric state variables (i.e. pressure, temperature, moisture, and momentum
label: BODY

text: fields) with an accuracy that falls within current measurement uncertainties.  Thus, at least in
label: BODY

text: observation-rich regions, today’s operational NWP analyses (and, by extension, multi-decadal
label: BODY

text: reanalyses) are demonstrably reliable references for accurately identifying errors in GCM
label: BODY

text: weather forecasts.
label: BODY

text: Moreover, the existence of high-quality NWP analyses makes it feasible to initialize a
label: BODY

text: climate GCM by methods that do not require developing a full-blown FDDA system for the
label: BODY

text: model (see Section 4.2).  If the initial state of the GCM is consistent with both the model
label: BODY

text: parameterizations and the NWP analyses and is also close to dynamical balance, the initialization
label: BODY

text: noise associated with gravity waves should be relatively small.  In that event, the forecast errors
label: BODY

text: will grow gradually (i.e. without sudden/sharp breaks) as the prediction period increases, and
label: BODY

text: most of the error growth that exceeds that of the inherent (in part, resolution-dependent)
label: BODY

text: predictability error will be attributable to deficiencies in the model parameterizations.
label: BODY

text: Although NWP analyses have previously been applied to the evaluation and development of
label: BODY

text: climate GCMs (e.g. Jeuken et al.1996, POTENTIALS 1999), such studies have focused on
label: BODY

text: analysis-forced integrations of these models.  CAPT's innovation is to recognize the value of
label: BODY

text: diagnosing a climate GCM’s weather forecasts, wherein the parameterizations are free to interact
label: BODY

text: with each other and with the model dynamics. Even though the forecast skill of a coarse-
label: BODY

text: resolution climate GCM is likely to be less than that of a fine-resolution NWP GCM, relative
label: BODY

text: improvement in the climate GCM's forecasts still should be attainable by making appropriate
label: BODY

text: changes in the model’s physical parameterizations.  Thus, CAPT's objective is not to improve the
label: BODY

text: short-range forecasts of a climate GCM per se, but rather to use weather forecasting as a context
label: BODY

text: for parameterization testing.
label: BODY

text: 2.3 Ancillary evaluation data
label: HH3

text: However, an NWP analysis is not sufficient to evaluate the GCM’s short-range forecast in
label: BODY

text: all respects: although the analysis is an optimal estimate of atmospheric state variables (given the
label: BODY

text: available weather observations), it cannot furnish precise checks on physical forcings such as
label: BODY

text: radiation and its interaction with clouds, convective processes, and turbulent fluxes.   That is,
label: BODY

text: although an NWP analysis includes estimates of such forcings, these depend strongly on the
label: BODY

text: physical parameterizations of the analysis GCM, and so are only indirectly related to the
label: BODY

text: assimilated observations.
label: BODY

text: Hence, for independent evaluation of GCM physical parameterizations, high-frequency
label: BODY

text: satellite data and field observations such as those provided by the ARM Program (Stokes and
label: BODY

text: Schwartz 1994) are indispensable--indeed,  their practical value for identifying GCM
label: BODY

text: parameterization problems has been amply demonstrated (e.g. Webb et al. 2001, Morcrette
label: BODY

text: 2002).  Of course, the physical consequences of changing particular parameterizations also can
label: BODY

text: be assessed using these ancillary data.  Moreover, field observations of state variables provide a
label: BODY

text: local check on the NWP analyses.
label: BODY

text: CAPT: Diagnostic Protocol
label: HH3

text: An overview of the proposed CAPt diagnostic protocol is illustrated by Figure 1. As a first
label: BODY

text: step, an appropriate regional case study is selected, based on availability of high-frequency
label: BODY

text: evaluation data (NWP analyses, satellite data, and field observations) that can effectively test a
label: BODY

text: candidate parameterization implemented in the climate GCM.  (Such candidates may include, for
label: BODY

text: example, radiation, convection, or cloud-formation schemes.)
label: BODY

text: The climate GCM’s state variables first are globally initialized from NWP analyses that are
label: BODY

text: remapped to the coarser resolution of the climate GCM and temporally interpolated for times
label: BODY

text: pertinent to the case study.  Climate GCM forecasts then are generated, with data archived at
label: BODY

text: regular intervals.  At each forecast interval, the departures of the GCM state variables from the
label: BODY

text: remapped NWP analysis data will be quantified by standard forecast skill scores. These metrics
label: BODY

text: also may be computed for forecasts that are stratified according to different synoptic regimes for
label: BODY

text: the case study region so as to identify model errors that are more obvious for particular
label: BODY

text: atmospheric conditions.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1: Schematic depiction of the CAPT diagnostic protocol.
label: HH3

text: If the candidate parameterization does not improve the overall forecast skill of the GCM
label: BODY

text: (e.g. relative to forecasts made with a "standard version" parameterization), the model developers
label: BODY

text: will need to formulate potential correctives.  To guide this process, the case study observations
label: BODY

text: of physical forcings can be used to infer connections between the GCM forecast errors and
label: BODY

text: physics errors, and in turn to suggest needed modifications in the candidate parameterization. At
label: BODY

text: this stage, other analysis tools such as single-column models (SCMs) and/or cloud-resolving
label: BODY

text: models (CRMs) also may be enlisted in developing an improved parameterization.
label: BODY

text: Whether these parameterization changes translate into actual model improvement will be
label: BODY

text: assessed by repeating all of the above diagnostic procedures for a new set of GCM forecasts.
label: BODY

text: General improvement in model forecast skill then will be tested further in climate simulations,
label: BODY

text: where the relevant evaluation will be determined from the statistics of the appropriate high-
label: BODY

text: frequency data over the simulation period.  A need for additional parameterization changes may,
label: BODY

text: of course, become obvious in these longer simulations.  When general improvements in the
label: BODY

text: climate statistics of the GCM have been demonstrated, the details will be documented in
label: BODY

text: technical reports and/or peer-reviewed publications that are coauthored by all participants.  The
label: BODY

text: entire process then may be repeated for another candidate parameterization.
label: BODY

text: CAPT: Technical Details
label: HH3

text: A prototype of the CAPT diagnostic protocol is presently being implemented for the NCAR
label: BODY

text: Community Atmospheric Model Version 2 (CAM2).  In this preliminary phase of the work,
label: BODY

text: many details are yet to be settled, so it is possible only to convey a general sense of the technical
label: BODY

text: issues to be addressed.  These are organized according to the elements of Figure 1, as follows.
label: BODY

text: 4.1 Evaluation data
label: HH3

text: CAPT will use the high-frequency (6-hourly) ERA-40 and NCEP R2 reanalyses (ECMWF
label: BODY

text: 2002, Kanamitsu et al. 2002), remapped to the coarser GCM resolution (e.g. spectral T42 with 26
label: BODY

text: vertical levels for CAM2), for primary evaluation of the model weather forecasts.  Such a
label: BODY

text: remapping is also necessary in using the reanalyses as target data for initializing these forecasts
label: BODY

text: (see Section 4.2).
label: BODY

text: Ancillary (field and satellite) data, available at 6-hourly and higher frequencies  (in some
label: BODY

text: cases, at frequencies comparable to GCM time steps), will provide independent checks on the
label: BODY

text: model forecast, and on other variables that are more directly related to parameterized processes.
label: BODY

text: Continuous field observations are available at selected points, notably at the ARM sites (ARM
label: BODY

text: 2002) in the U.S. Southern Great Plains (SGP), the North Slope of Alaska (NSA), and the
label: BODY

text: Tropical West Pacific (TWP).
label: BODY

text: The most comprehensive set of high-frequency observations are presently available during
label: BODY

text: sporadic intensive observation periods (IOPs), but ARM increasingly is providing continuous
label: BODY

text: records of these data sets. Selected examples at the ARM SGP site include:
label: BODY

text: • Radiosonde soundings of temperature and humidity at 3-hourly frequencies at the SGP
label: BODY

text: central facility (CF) near Lamont, Oklahoma, as well as at 4 neighboring stations. (These
label: BODY

text: can provide independent local checks on NWP analyses.)
label: BODY

text: • Wind profiler measurements at hourly frequencies;
label: BODY

text: • Solar Infrared Radiation Station (SIRS) measurements of surface upwelling/downwelling
label: BODY

text: longwave and shortwave irradiances at 1-minute frequencies;
label: BODY

text: • Energy Budget Bowen Ratio (EBBR) measurements of surface latent and sensible heat
label: BODY

text: fluxes at 30-minute frequencies;
label: BODY

text: • Microwave Radiometer (MWR) measurements of column precipitable water and total
label: BODY

text: cloud liquid water at 5-minute frequencies;
label: BODY

text: • Surface Meteorological Observation Stations (SMOS) and Oklahoma and Kansas Mesonet
label: BODY

text: stations (OKM and KAM) observations of surface meteorology (precipitation, pressure,
label: BODY

text: winds, temperature, and relative humidity) at 5 to 30-minute frequencies.
label: BODY

text: In addition, collocated Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite (GOES)
label: BODY

text: temperature and dew point retrievals are available at 30-minute frequencies.
label: BODY

text: Similar types of point field data also are available at a few other locations where
label: BODY

text: international Global Energy and Water Cycle Experiment (GEWEX) Continental-Scale
label: BODY

text: Experiments have been conducted (CSE 2002). There also are plans to expand this observational
label: BODY

text: network to some 30 sites during the 2003-2004 GEWEX Coordinated Enhanced Observing
label: BODY

text: Period (CEOP 2002).
label: BODY

text: Other potentially relevant evaluation data include coordinated satellite, aircraft, and surface
label: BODY

text: measurements that have been collected during one-time field campaigns. Many of these have
label: BODY

text: been centralized by the GEWEX International Satellite Cloud Climatology Project (ISCCP), in
label: BODY

text: particular for several locations and time periods that are under intensive investigation by
label: BODY

text: GEWEX Cloud System Study participants (GCSS 2002).
label: BODY

text: To make these point observations fully relevant for model evaluation, they need to be
label: BODY

text: aggregated to the scale of a GCM grid box. To this end, some of the ARM SGP data has been
label: BODY

text: subjected to objective variational analysis (Zhang and Lin1997, Zhang, et al. 2000). This method
label: BODY

text: uses the domain-averaged surface precipitation and latent and sensible heat fluxes as well as the
label: BODY

text: surface and top-of-atmosphere (TOA) radiative fluxes to constrain the atmospheric variables, so
label: BODY

text: that heat, moisture, and momentum are conserved.  Thus, the resulting derived data are
label: BODY

text: dynamically and thermodynamically consistent.
label: BODY

text: Another complication of using such ancillary data for model evaluation is that a "forward
label: BODY

text: model" (e.g. Morcrette 1991, Klein and Jakob 1999) often must be applied to translate the
label: BODY

text: GCM’s output variables into relevant observables (e.g. band radiances, cloud reflectivies, etc.).
label: BODY

text: For example, the ISSCP cloud simulator (Webb 2002) is currently being incorporated in the
label: BODY

text: CAM2 model. In addition, modifications of the model’s standard configuration (e.g. increasing
label: BODY

text: the frequency of the radiation calculations and of the archiving of model output) may be
label: BODY

text: necessary to match the frequency of the observations.
label: BODY

text: 4.2 Model initialization
label: HH2

text: In order to isolate a climate GCM's parameterization-related errors, proper initialization of
label: BODY

text: the climate GCM (initially, CAM2) is crucial for minimizing noise resulting from an unbalanced
label: BODY

text: land/atmosphere initial state and for producing needed unobserved variables (e.g. cloud water
label: BODY

text: and ice, soil moisture and temperature profile, etc.).  Hence, CAPT is currently investigating the
label: BODY

text: relative merits of two standard techniques--"nudging" and "forecast-analysis"--for initializing a
label: BODY

text: model's atmospheric state variables using an NWP analysis as target data
label: BODY

text: Nudging (e.g. Jeuken et al. 1996) attempts to steer atmospheric variable α toward that of the
label: BODY

text: corresponding analysis variable ?α0  (that is interpolated to the model's horizontal/vertical grid) by
label: BODY

text: adding a Newtonian relaxation term to the relevant prognostic equation:
label: BODY

text: Dα/Dt = F(α, x, t) + (α0 −α)/τ
label: BODY

text: Here F includes all spatio-temporal forcings, and the relaxation time constant  τ may be
label: BODY

text: specific to each nudged variable α (e.g. including atmospheric temperature T, winds u/v, surface
label: BODY

text: pressure Ps, and humidity q). Nudging is currently implemented at every model time step for six
label: BODY

text: months prior to the first forecast (see schematic in Figure 2a).  This lengthy integration serves to
label: BODY

text: spin up "slow" CAM2 land variables (e.g. soil moisture/temperature and snow cover) to a state in
label: BODY

text: which the associated surface radiative and turbulent fluxes are consistent with the nudged model
label: BODY

text: atmosphere.  Aside from this long spin-up period, the chief disadvantage of implementing the
label: BODY

text: nudging technique is that the model prognostic equations must be modified to include the
label: BODY

text: necessary relaxation terms.
label: BODY

text: Nudging Technique
label: HH3

text: Atm
label: BODY

text: Land
label: BODY

text: Forecast
label: BODY

text: Time
label: BODY

text: Atmospheric T, u,v,Ps,q are nudged at every time step
label: BODY

text: for 6 months prior to the first forecast
label: BODY

text: Figure 2a: Schematic depiction of the nudging initialization technique.
label: HH3

text: Such model code changes are not needed in implementing the forecast-analysis technique
label: BODY

text: (e.g. Harrison et al. 1999).  In this approach, the model’s forecast (including unobserved
label: BODY

text: variables) is compared directly to the NWP analysis at six-hour intervals, and a fractional
label: BODY

text: difference between forecast and analysis (the "increment") is added repeatedly to the evolving
label: BODY

text: model atmospheric state.  (When the entire difference between the forecast and the analysis is
label: BODY

text: added, the forecast-analysis technique is identical to "full-field insertion".)  As in the nudging
label: BODY

text: technique, the model's slow land variables adjust so that the surface fluxes are consistent with the
label: BODY

text: updated atmospheric state (Figure 2b). A disadvantage of forecast-analysis is that the model's
label: BODY

text: atmospheric state variables must be mapped to the analysis data grid, and the increment mapped
label: BODY

text: back to the model grid.  In addition, it may be necessary to apply a digital filter in order to damp
label: BODY

text: gravity waves which may be more extensive when initializing by the forecast-analysis technique
label: BODY

text: (Lynch and Huang 1992, Polavarapu et al. 2000).
label: BODY

text: Atm
label: BODY

text: Land
label: BODY

text: Forecast-Analysis Technique
label: HH1

text: T,u,v,Ps,q
label: BODY

text: T,u,v,Ps,q
label: BODY

text: T,u,v,Ps,q
label: BODY

text: Forecast
label: BODY

text: Time
label: BODY

text: The land model is restarted prior to the forecast
label: BODY

text: Figure 2b: Schematic depiction of the forecast-analysis initialization technique.
label: BODY

text: CAPT is currently applying both of these initialization techniques in studies designed to
label: BODY

text: estimate the magnitude of initialization errors in different contexts.  For example, a "perfect
label: BODY

text: model" study is estimating the irreducible part of the CAM2 initialization error by using the
label: BODY

text: model's own outputs as the target data set. Preliminary results indicate the need to nudge the
label: BODY

text: model for as long as ~ 6 months, depending on the seasonally dependent adjustment time of the
label: BODY

text: slower land and snow processes. In addition, a "perfect analysis" study is providing estimates of
label: BODY

text: the minimum initialization error to be expected when the NCEP R2 reanalysis is used for
label: BODY

text: initializing the associated NCEP GCM.
label: BODY

text: A "practical initialization" study is also underway to assess the relative merits of nudging vs.
label: BODY

text: forecast-analysis methods for initialization of the model atmosphere using the ERA-40 reanalysis
label: BODY

text: as target data. Thus far, the principal technical issue concerns how to appropriately remap the
label: BODY

text: reanalysis surface pressure and net downward radiation to the coarser model resolution, given the
label: BODY

text: associated large differences in topographic elevations.  Following Morcrette (2002), initialization
label: BODY

text: noise is judged to be tolerable if a 30+ day time series formed by concatenation of a sequence of
label: BODY

text: forecasts started at fixed intervals apart show qualitatively similar features, without evincing
label: BODY

text: sudden/sharp breaks.
label: BODY

text: Another unresolved issue is whether the CAM2 land model (Bonan et al. 2002) should be
label: BODY

text: initialized in a different way than in the current practice of "slaving" it to the atmospheric model.
label: BODY

text: Here, at least three different approaches might be pursued.  Using the initialization of the soil
label: BODY

text: moisture profile as an example, these methods are summarized below, in ascending order of
label: BODY

text: implementation difficulty:
label: BODY

text: • Remapping a reanalysis soil moisture profile to that of the climate model, subject to
label: BODY

text: maintaining equivalent soil moisture availabilities (personal communication, P. Viterbo,
label: BODY

text: M. Best, and H. Douville).
label: BODY

text: • Scaling of the mean and variance of the reanalysis soil moisture profile, where the scaling
label: BODY

text: coefficients are estimated from a multi-year run of the climate model made with observed
label: BODY

text: sea surface temperatures as ocean boundary conditions (personal communication, M.
label: BODY

text: Kanamitsu).
label: BODY

text: • Specifying soil moisture profiles from a multi-annual off-line or coupled integration of the
label: BODY

text: climate model's land scheme forced by estimates of observed terrestrial precipitation and
label: BODY

text: surface insolation (personal communication P. Dirmeyer, R. Koster, and K. Mitchell).
label: BODY

text: In practice, it will be necessary to strike a compromise between a land initialization scheme
label: BODY

text: that can be easily implemented versus one that yields a close initial land-atmosphere balance, but
label: BODY

text: at excessive computational cost.
label: BODY

text: 4.3 Model forecasts
label: HH2

text: Although much useful diagnostic information can be gleaned in the course of initializing the
label: BODY

text: model, intrinsic behaviors are more fully revealed in forecasts.  For example, the observed
label: BODY

text: propensity of the CAM2 atmosphere to dry excessively when nudged toward the NWP
label: BODY

text: reanalyses is even more evident in its forecasts of atmospheric moisture at the ARM SGP site
label: BODY

text: (apparently related to incorrect forecast of precipitation events and/or amounts). This pattern is
label: BODY

text: evident whether the forecasts are compared to the corresponding nudged initial states (Figure 3)
label: BODY

text: or to ARM field observations (Figure 4). These results are thought to be linked to deficiencies in
label: BODY

text: the CAM’s convective triggering mechanism over land (Xie et al. 2002).
label: BODY

text: The current CAPT practice is to generate 3-day (0-72 hour) CAM2 forecasts, with data
label: BODY

text: archived every 3 hours.  A new 3-day forecast is started at 00Z for each day of the time period of
label: BODY

text: interest (e.g. during an ARM IOP), where the model atmosphere is initialized by application of
label: BODY

text: either nudging or forecast-analysis techniques.
label: BODY

text: Both the magnitude of forecast errors and their growth rate are of diagnostic value.  These
label: BODY

text: aspects of the forecast can be quantified using standard NWP metrics, for example by computing
label: BODY

text: the temporal variation of the mean bias and the root-mean-square (RMS) error (yielding error
label: BODY

text: amplitude information) or that of the anomaly correlation coefficient (yielding error pattern
label: BODY

text: information).
label: BODY

text: time
label: BODY

text: level
label: BODY

text: Figure 3: Evolution over three-day intervals (for arbitrarily numbered days 190-193) of ensemble-
label: HH3

text: mean differences between forecasts of the vertical profile of CAM2 specific humidity and nudged-run
label: BODY

text: profiles (on pressure levels in hPa) for the ARM SGP site. The ensemble-mean difference is computed
label: BODY

text: over 10 three-day forecasts and corresponding nudged runs during the period 1-10 July of the 1997
label: BODY

text: IOP. Note the anomalous drying of the lower troposphere (negative forecast-minus-nudged humidity
label: BODY

text: differences, denoted by cooler colors) that intensifies with time over the three-day interval.
label: BODY

text: Figure 4: Ensemble-mean of 29 three-day forecasts of precipitable water at the ARM SGP site
label: HH3

text: during June/July 1997 and corresponding mean 3-hourly observations. Note that the model
label: BODY

text: erroneously forecasts atmospheric drying and an attenuated diurnal cycle.
label: BODY

text: Figure 5, for example, shows spatially averaged anomaly correlations of 3-day forecasts of
label: BODY

text: 500 hPa heights by the CAM2 model versus remapped 6-hourly ERA-40 reanalysis data.  Here, a
label: BODY

text: different 3-day forecast is generated at 00Z for each day of the 19 June-18 July 1997 ARM IOP,
label: BODY

text: where the initial conditions are obtained by nudging the CAM2 atmospheric state variables and
label: BODY

text: surface pressure toward the corresponding remapped ERA-40 reanalysis data.
label: BODY

text: The anomaly correlations of different forecasts in Figure 5 decrease fairly smoothly
label: BODY

text: with time, suggesting that the initial CAM2 500 hPa heights are sufficiently balanced by the
label: BODY

text: nudging to reduce the initialization noise in this variable to a tolerable level.  However, the
label: BODY

text: anomaly correlations of separate forecasts are of different initial magnitudes and fall off at
label: BODY

text: varying rates with time, implying a sensitivity to synoptic conditions.  This sensitivity will be
label: BODY

text: exploited in diagnosing the model's parameterizations.
label: BODY

text: Figure 5: Spatially averaged (over latitudes 25N-90N) anomaly correlations of three-day
label: HH3

text: CAM2 forecasts of 500 hPa height versus ERA-40 reanalysis during June/July 1997.
label: BODY

text: The ensemble-mean anomaly correlation is indicated by the darker line.
label: BODY

text: 4.4 Model parameterization diagnosis
label: HH2

text: The attribution of forecast errors to deficiencies in model parameterizations and the
label: BODY

text: subsequent correction of these schemes are central to the improvement of climate GCMs.   Since
label: BODY

text: most parameterization deficiencies will be more starkly revealed under certain weather
label: BODY

text: conditions, CAPT will diagnose CAM2 forecasts that are stratified according to regional
label: BODY

text: synoptic conditions (e.g. clear vs. cloudy, dry vs. wet, summer vs. winter cases, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Because of the highly nonlinear character of GCMs, it is rarely easy to draw connections
label: BODY

text: between forecast errors in the atmospheric state variables and the physical forcings that are
label: BODY

text: governed by the model's parameterizations.  Thus, CAPT will analyze CAM2 forecasts that are
label: BODY

text: coincident with case studies (e.g. short-term field campaigns, ARM IOPs, etc.) where available
label: BODY

text: high-frequency field data can augment the reanalyses by providing independent checks on model
label: BODY

text: physics and state variables. CAPT analysis of such case studies will attempt to identify a
label: BODY

text: recurring connection between a forecast error in a state variable and anomalous physical forcing
label: BODY

text: that can be tied to particular deficiencies in a selected parameterization.
label: BODY

text: When a problematical connection of this type is found, CAPT will report the
label: BODY

text: forecast/forcing error metrics and related phenomenological details to GCM developers and
label: BODY

text: collaborating parameterization specialists so that they have a basis to formulate potential
label: BODY

text: correctives for the relevant parameterization. In addition, before a modified parameterization is
label: BODY

text: implemented in the climate GCM, parameterization developers may test it in a single-column
label: BODY

text: and/or cloud-resolving model (SCM and CRM), and in a simplified (e.g. linearized, aqua-planet,
label: BODY

text: etc.) GCM (e.g. Xie et al. 2002, Xu et al. 2002).
label: BODY

text: Once a new scheme is implemented in the climate model, it will be extensively tested to
label: BODY

text: determine whether a reduction in forecast errors results for the case study in question, as well as
label: BODY

text: for other initial conditions.  A parameterization that produces global reductions in forecast errors
label: BODY

text: will also need to be tested in long integrations so that its effects on the simulation of different
label: BODY

text: climate processes can be assessed.  Moreover, even if a new parameterization is successful in
label: BODY

text: reducing certain types of climate errors, it is likely that the GCM's other parameterizations will
label: BODY

text: need to be "retuned" before its climate simulation displays overall improvement. In that event,
label: BODY

text: this new version of the climate model will be the starting point for testing additional
label: BODY

text: parameterization changes.
label: BODY

text: Summary
label: HH3

text: CAPT is motivated by the historical experience that it is exceedingly difficult to unravel
label: BODY

text: parameterization deficiencies solely by diagnosing a GCM’s climate statistics, which reflect
label: BODY

text: systematic biases resulting from the convolution of nonlinear/nonlocal interactions of many
label: BODY

text: different schemes.  Instead, the starting point of the CAPT protocol is to focus on the short-range
label: BODY

text: forecasts of the climate GCM, and to closely compare these against well-sampled observations
label: BODY

text: provided by NWP analyses and satellite/field data as the first criterion for assessing model
label: BODY

text: performance/improvement.
label: BODY

text: Thus, new parameterizations will be considered for testing in GCM climate simulations only
label: BODY

text: after they improve the model's weather forecasts.  It should not be expected, however, that the
label: BODY

text: transition from the short-range to climate scales will be entirely straightforward--further model
label: BODY

text: adjustments may be needed before overall improvement in the climate simulation is evident.
label: BODY

text: Hence, the CAPT protocol should not be viewed as a panacea, but only as one element in a
label: BODY

text: hierarchy of techniques (including, for example, diagnostics based on single-column, cloud-
label: BODY

text: resolving, and simplified global models) to bolster the observational/ scientific foundations of
label: BODY

text: climate model development. Nevertheless, it is anticipated that important insights on improving
label: BODY

text: climate GCMs will flow from adopting this NWP-inspired methodology.
label: BODY
